channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russian Missiles Hit Kyiv, as Putin Issues Warning to the West
item.description: The first strikes in the capital in more than a month destroyed tanks supplied by Ukraine’s allies, Russia said. President Vladimir Putin warned that Moscow would hit new targets if Western nations delivered longer-range missiles to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crater left from a Russian missile strike on the outskirts of Druzhkivka, in eastern Ukraine, on Sunday. One woman was killed, a regional official said.

item.title: ‘From Russia With Love’: A Putin Ally Mines Gold and Plays Favorites in Sudan
item.description: Backed by the Kremlin, the shadowy network known as the Wagner Group is getting rich in Sudan while helping the military to crush a democracy movement.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Abdulmonam Eassa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian gold processing plant in the desert outside al-Ibediyya, 200 miles north of the Sudanese capital, Khartoum.

item.title: New Zealand’s Biodiversity Crisis Prompts Extreme Measures
item.description: A few years ago, the nation vowed to rid itself of most imported predators. But now some people are asking if that goal is feasible, or worth what it will cost.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:description: Louise Davidson with Predator Free Wellington, setting up a trap on a coastal part of the Miramar Peninsula, south of New Zealand’s capital, Wellington.

item.title: A Farmer Holds On, a Fraying Lifeline for a Besieged Corner of Ukraine
item.description: Most farmers have fled the Russian advance, but Oleksandr Chaplik has stayed, despite the lethal risks and a lack of workers, water and power.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: “My nerves are cracking,” said Oleksandr Chaplik, a farmer who has kept his besieged corner of Ukraine linked to the outside world.

item.title: Jubilee Honors Queen Elizabeth, but Also Highlights Her Increasing Absences
item.description: Throngs of admirers cheered Queen Elizabeth II at her Platinum Jubilee appearance on Thursday, but she was unable to attend a service on Friday. Prince Charles, in a familiar role, played the understudy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Chris Jackson
item.media:description: Projections depicting Queen Elizabeth II’s 70-year reign displayed on the front of Buckingham Palace on Thursday.

item.title: On the Anniversary of Tiananmen Massacre, Victims Remembered
item.description: In Taiwan and elsewhere, people met on Saturday to remember those killed in China in 1989 — and the freedoms lost in Hong Kong, where such vigils are now unthinkable.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Chris Buckley, Austin Ramzy and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A candlelight vigil in Taipei, Taiwan, on Saturday. The city has emerged as a new center for remembrance after Hong Kong’s commemorations were essentially banned.

item.title: Gaza Bodybuilders Feel Weight of Israeli Blockade
item.description: Bodybuilding is popular among Palestinians living in Gaza, but travel restrictions and other obstacles as a result of the Israeli blockade make competing abroad a struggle.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suhail al-Asaad, a top Palestinian bodybuilder, working out at a gym in Gaza.

item.title: In the U.K., Migrants From Hong Kong Build a New Life
item.description: More than a year after they first began arriving in Britain under a new visa program, people from Hong Kong are settling into their new home. But they still long for the one they left behind.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kago Ng; her husband, Valen Liu; and their son, Kaspar, enjoying a traditional Hong Kong hotpot in their apartment in Sutton, England, where they moved last year.

item.title: Senior Iranian Officer Dies, Leaving Questions About His Death
item.description: Col. Ali Esmaelzadeh was the second high-ranking officer of the same unit to die in a week. The circumstances were unclear, and Iranian news media provided conflicting reports.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps in an annual military parade in Tehran in 2018.

item.title: In the Philippines, a Doctor Unearths a Drug War’s True Toll
item.description: Raquel Fortun, one of only two forensic pathologists in the Philippines, is using her skills to show how other doctors falsely claimed some victims of the country’s drug war had died natural deaths.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ezra Acayan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Raquel Fortun, a forensic pathologist, inspecting the skeletal remains of a drug war victim at a classroom in Manila in May.

item.title: Thousands Swept Up as Kremlin Clamps Down on War Criticism
item.description: The arrests are a stark gauge of how the Kremlin has intensified repression of critics. At least 50 people now face years-long prison sentences.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irpin, a suburb of Kyiv, was left in ruin early last month after Russian forces withdrew. The Russian government has imposed strict laws to silence critics of the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Hindus in Kashmir Desperate to Flee Amid Spike in Attacks
item.description: Decades after militant violence forced many of them out of the disputed region, hundreds of families have left in another exodus.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Showkat Nanda for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Vessu camp in Kashmir. One-third of the 900 families there have fled their modest houses, most with belongings that could fit into the back of small vehicles.

item.title: Israel Builds a Laser Weapon to Zap Threats Out of the Sky
item.description: From science fiction to facts in the air: Israel says a prototype downed rockets and drones in recent tests.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

item.title: The Jack Welch Effect
item.description: His ruthlessness as General Electric’s C.E.O. was ultimately bad for the company, a new book argues.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Welch before his retirement in 2001.

item.title: Dozens Killed and Hundreds Burned in Bangladesh Depot Disaster
item.description: A fire set off a series of explosions, killing at least 49 people, including firefighters. Many others were in critical condition.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Firefighters on Sunday were still trying to contain a blaze that began late Saturday night at a container depot in Sitakunda, Bangladesh.

item.title: North Korea Launches a Volley of Short-Range Missiles
item.description: The North’s latest test, involving eight missiles, came a day after the United States and South Korea finished joint naval exercises in the East China Sea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA via KNS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, in April. The North has carried out 18 weapons tests this year.

item.title: Ukraine aims to restart soccer leagues on its own soil in August.
item.description: In an interview with The Associated Press, the leader of Ukraine’s soccer federation said President Volodymyr Zelensky had approved the decision.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: As Battles Rage, Ukraine Rejects Macron Plea Not to ‘Humiliate’ Russia
item.description: Amid reports of battlefield gains by Ukraine, an official angrily rejected Mr. Macron’s advice, saying it “can only humiliate France.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a frontline position near Donetsk in eastern Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine Official Says Forces Pushed Back Russians in Eastern City
item.description: Ukrainian forces poured men and armor toward the front line in Sievierodonetsk on Friday, and a military official said Ukrainian troops had managed to push Russian forces back by 20 percent.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A jet, most likely Russian, fired flares over Ukrainian frontline positions in May.

item.title: London Police Evacuate Trafalgar Square, but Say ‘Incident Has Now Been Concluded’
item.description: The evacuation of the square in Central London rattled the capital on the third day of Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee. The police later said it was not related to terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Phil Noble/Reuters
item.media:description: The police removed a car after a security incident near Trafalgar Square on Saturday in London.

item.title: Summer Vacation Movies
item.description: They offer a double dose of escape.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada Tightens Gun Laws Amid a Wave of Mass Shootings in the U.S.
item.description: The handgun market in Canada has been frozen as Parliament reviews sweeping legal changes, including a mandatory buyback of some rifles.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jesse Winter/Reuters
item.media:description: Canada’s freeze on handguns will not require Parliament’s approval.

item.title: Zelensky Tells U.S. Mayors to End Their Sister-City Ties with Russia
item.description: The Ukrainian president said the relationships allow Moscow to say ‘it is not isolated.’
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Office of the President of Ukraine/The Associated Press

item.title: ‘We Have Not Forgotten Syria’: U.S. Envoy Vows to Protect Refugees
item.description: After 11 years of war, Syria has become a cautionary example of what can happen in a conflict with no end in sight, like the one that began 100 days ago in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Michelle Nichols/Reuters
item.media:description: The American ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, visited the Syrian border near Hatay, Turkey, on Thursday to assess a long-running U.N. operation delivering humanitarian aid into northwest Syria.

item.title: Russia Needs Friends. Africa, Needing Food, Isn’t Turning Its Back.
item.description: A meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the head of the African Union, President Macky Sall of Senegal, showed that Africa is not prepared to cut ties to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A storage facility for grain on the outskirts of Lviv, Ukraine. African countries are heavily dependent on grain from Russia and Ukraine.

item.title: Covid Vaccine Misinformation Still Fuels Fears Surrounding Pregnancy, a New Study Finds.
item.description: Health experts, including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, recommend that pregnant women get vaccinated against the coronavirus as soon as possible, to protect both maternal and fetal health.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Experts say that widespread doubts about the safety of coronavirus vaccines for pregnant women are baseless.

item.title: 100 Days of War in Ukraine: Death, Destruction and Loss
item.description: The grinding conflict in Ukraine has rocked the global order, wrought destruction that “defies comprehension” and shows little sign of ending soon.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Steven Erlanger and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers being examined for injuries and ailments at an aid station in the city of Bakhmut, on Friday.

item.title: 21 Americans Infected With Monkeypox, C.D.C. Reports
item.description: As the number of cases outside Africa approaches 800, governments are scrambling for a limited pool of vaccines and treatments with unclear effectiveness.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Lukas Barth/Reuters
item.media:description: A Bavarian Nordic lab in Germany. The company has produced a vaccine effective against monkeypox.

item.title: Most Canadians Want to See the British Monarchy Come to an End
item.description: In a recent poll, 67 percent of respondents said they opposed the idea of Charles succeeding his mother to become Canada’s king.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Reuters
item.media:description: Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, leaving Canada after a tour of the country last month.

item.title: Carbon Dioxide Levels Are Highest in Human History
item.description: Humans pumped 36 billion tons of the planet-warming gas into the atmosphere in 2021, more than in any previous year. It comes from burning oil, gas and coal.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Susan Cobb/NOAA
item.media:description: The Mauna Loa Atmospheric Baseline Observatory in Hawaii began measuring the amount of carbon in the atmosphere in 1958.

item.title: Could Australia and New Zealand ‘Divorce’ From the British Monarchy?
item.description: The debate over whether to sever ties with Britain’s royal family has traditionally attracted little mainstream interest in the two members of the Commonwealth.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Cole Bennetts/Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II visiting Canberra, Australia’s capital, in October 2011.

item.title: Alameda County in California Reinstates Indoor Mask Mandate
item.description: Officials cited growing hospitalizations in reimposing the policy.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: Alameda County, Calif., home to Oakland, has ordered a mask mandate in most indoor public spaces.

item.title: At Least 4 Dead After Train Derails in Germany
item.description: Rescue crews from Austria were helping on the scene in southern Germany, where more than a dozen people were taken to a hospital with serious injuries.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Josef Hornsteiner/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency crews responding after a serious train accident on Friday near Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany.

item.title: Caribbean Nations Reassess British Crown, in Wake of Black Lives Matter
item.description: Public sentiment toward the monarchy has soured in the region, and calls for reparations for Britain’s often brutal role in the slave trade have been rising.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jane Barlow/REUTERS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Andrew Holness of Jamaica, right, with Prince William in Kingston, the Jamaican capital, during the prince’s Platinum Jubilee royal tour of the Caribbean in March.

item.title: U.K.’s ‘Brightest and Best’ Visa Leaves Out Africa, India and Latin America
item.description: Under the new program, graduates of top-ranked global colleges can move to Britain for two years, even without a job offer. But critics say the plan nurtures global inequalities.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Alexander Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Canary Wharf business district in London. A goal of the new visa program is to “build the businesses of tomorrow,” a government minister said.

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Make Their First Appearance at the Jubilee
item.description: The appearance by Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, at St. Paul’s Cathedral on Friday was their first official royal outing since early 2020.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kirsty O'Connor
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, entering St. Paul’s Cathedral on Friday.

item.title: At Least 18 Mass Shootings Have Happened in the U.S. So Far This Year
item.description: The Tulsa mass shooting wasn’t as deadly as some feared. Instead, it was yet another American tragedy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Nick Oxford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers block an intersection at Saint Francis Hospital in Tulsa, Okla.

item.title: For Boris Johnson, a Welcome Break From Political Pressures
item.description: His attendance at the service of thanksgiving during the Platinum Jubilee celebrations for Queen Elizabeth II is also an opportunity to stride the global stage and rub shoulders with royalty.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Phil Noble
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his wife, Carrie Johnson, in St. Paul’s Cathedral in London on Friday.

item.title: What to Know About Great Paul Bell at St. Paul’s Cathedral
item.description: The London cathedral’s bronze bell, weighing over 16 tons, is the largest bell ever cast in the British Isles.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Hulton-Deutsch Collection/Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Great Paul, cast in the late 1800s, weighs over 16 tons.

item.title: Driving Iceland’s Overlooked North
item.description: For those seeking an alternative to the popular Golden Circle, the Diamond Circle winds through volcanic landscapes featuring powerful waterfalls, misty vistas and sulfurous pools.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine says Russia controls 20 percent of its territory.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Donetsk on Thursday.

item.title: When Freedom Is Only the Beginning
item.description: Refugees who’d spent years in detention had a lot of questions about their new lives in Australia. Some were easier to answer than others.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refugee from Iran outside his Melbourne motel room in April.

item.title: As War Approaches 100th Day, Russia Now Controls a Fifth of Ukraine
item.description: While President Volodymyr Zelensky acknowledged Russian gains, Ukrainian forces pressed a counteroffensive in the south.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marharita Prohora, 6, stands in front of her grandmother’s home, which was destroyed on March 13 in Russian strikes, in the village of Andriivka, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Communities Light Beacons to Honor Queen Elizabeth II in U.K. and Beyond
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II led the lighting of a beacon at Windsor Castle, and her grandson Prince William lit one outside Buckingham Palace on Thursday night.
item.dc:creator: Randy Pennell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Steve Parsons
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth led the lighting of the principal Jubilee beacon at Windsor Castle on Thursday night.

item.title: Now It’s Türkiye, Not Turkey, at the United Nations
item.description: The Turkish government wants the rest of the world to use the country’s own name for itself, and lose the association with a certain bird.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Burhan Ozbilici/Associated Press

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Has Seized One-Fifth of Ukraine
item.description: Plus South Korea’s conservatives win big and the queen celebrates 70 years on the throne.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children in a park in Borodianka, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: African Union Head Will Urge Putin to Release Ukraine’s Grain
item.description: Amid fears of a global food crisis, the president of Senegal is to meet with the president of Russia at a Black Sea resort on Friday. Aides say he will speak of the risk of famine in Africa.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Pool photo by John Thys
item.media:description: President Macky Sall of Senegal, the African Union’s chairman, will meet with President Vladimir V. Putin in Sochi.

item.title: Biden to Travel to Saudi Arabia, Ending Its ‘Pariah’ Status
item.description: As a candidate, President Biden vowed to punish the kingdom for the brutal assassination of Jamal Khashoggi. But now he wants to rebuild relations as he seeks to lower gas prices and isolate Russia.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Hamad I Mohammed/Reuters
item.media:description: President Biden is expected to meet with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman when he visits Saudi Arabia this month.

item.title: Prince Andrew Tests Positive and Will Miss Jubilee Event on Friday
item.description: The thanksgiving service was the only major event of the Platinum Jubilee that the prince had been expected to attend.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Peter Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Prince Andrew on the Royal Estate in Windsor, England, on Wednesday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee Celebrates Her 70 Years on the Throne
item.description: The dysfunction of the royal family was pushed temporarily offstage on Thursday by a joyful celebration of its 96-year-old matriarch, whose reign has been an anchor for her country.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Chris Jackson/Chris Jackson Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the public line the Mall during Trooping the Color on Thursday in London.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth will skip Friday’s church service after ‘discomfort’ during the jubilee’s first day.
item.description: The queen will not attend a thanksgiving service on Friday that is a major event of her Platinum Jubilee.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II of Britain on the balcony of Buckingham Palace during the Platinum Jubilee celebrations on Thursday.

item.title: In Photos: Queen Elizabeth II Celebrates Her Platinum Jubilee
item.description: The royal family gathered at Buckingham Palace to kick off a joyful commemorative weekend marking Elizabeth II’s 70 years as queen.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Aaron Chown

item.title: Why Canada Races on Gun Policy When America Crawls
item.description: The speed of policymaking in Canada, and its frequent deadlock in the U.S., may come down to the rules of their political systems.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Jennifer Gauthier/Reuters
item.media:description: At a firing range in Langley, British Columbia, this week.

item.title: W.H.O Predicts Steep Drop in Covid Deaths in Africa in 2022
item.description: A study by the World Health Organization says that more than half the region’s population now has some level of immunity, mainly from unreported past infections.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Ngouda Dione/Reuters
item.media:description: Administering a coronavirus vaccine in Banjul, Gambia, last month.

item.title: Dead Dolphins May Be Casualties of Ukraine War, Scientist Say
item.description: The washing up of dolphins on the coasts of Bulgaria, Romania, Turkey and Ukraine is raising concerns that the war in may be interfering with marine life. But more research is needed, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mehmet Eser/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
item.media:description: A dolphin near Istanbul in 2020. Injured dolphins have been washing up on the coasts of Bulgaria, Romania, Turkey and Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Technology, a Longtime Tool for Russia, Becomes a Vulnerability
item.description: Global restrictions on sending advanced technology to Russia are hampering the country’s military capacity, U.S. officials say, though Russia has stockpiled American equipment for years.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, John Ismay and Edward Wong

item.title: Americans Visit London for the Queen’s Jubilee
item.description: They traveled from afar to celebrate Queen Elizabeth II’s 70-year reign.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Donna Werner, a Queen Elizabeth II fan from Connecticut, with a tent she had set up outside Buckingham Palace on Tuesday for the queen’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations.

item.title: E.P.A., Reversing Trump, Will Restore States’ Power to Block Pipelines
item.description: A proposed rule would make it easier for state officials and tribal authorities to stop pipelines and other energy projects that could pollute local waters.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration last year near Park Rapids, Minn., against the Line 3 pipeline project.

item.title: Ukraine Tells Story of War in Museum Show
item.description: The exhibition, called “Crucified Ukraine,” is one of several ways that the country’s government is highlighting the devastation that its people have endured.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A propeller from a destroyed Russian helicopter, right, and other fragments of military equipment at the “Crucified Ukraine” show in Kyiv, the country’s capital.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Yacht Company That Caters to Russian Elites
item.description: The Treasury Department also identified four yachts as being linked to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Michael Forsythe
